20,000 (in 2018){{cite web|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/syrian-government-deliberately-starved-eastern-ghouta-un-1553093123 |title=Both sides committed war crimes during Eastern Ghouta siege: UN |author= |work=[[Middle East Eye]] |date=20 June 2018 |accessdate=22 June 2018 }}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/02/28/world/middleeast/ap-ml-syria-ghoutas-fighters.html|title=Thousands of Well-Armed Rebel Fighters Are in Syria's Ghouta|first=The Associated|last=Press|date=28 February 2018|work=The New York Times|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228162402/https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/02/28/world/middleeast/ap-ml-syria-ghoutas-fighters.html|archivedate=28 February 2018|df=dmy-all}} | strength2 = 15,000 (in 2018) | casualties1 = 10,000+ killed (2012–18)[https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/map-update-syrian-army-takes-last-rebel-held-district-of-east-ghouta-ends-six-year-battle/ Map update: Syrian Army takes last rebel-held district of East Ghouta, ends six year battle] | casualties2 = 10,000+ killed (2012–18) | casualties3 = 12,763 killed civilians
(March 2011 to February 2018, per [[Syrian Network for Human Rights|SNHR]]){{cite web| title=Approximately 13,000 Civilians Killed at the Hands of Syrian Regime Forces in Eastern Ghouta, including 1,463 Children| url=http://sn4hr.org/wp-content/pdf/english/The_ongoing_massacre_en.pdf| publisher=[[Syrian Network for Human Rights|SNHR]]| date=February 25, 2018| accessdate=15 March 2018}}
~18,000 killed overall
(Eastern Ghouta hospital sources, 2017){{cite web| title= En Syrie, les faubourgs rebelles de Damas affamés|language=French| url=http://www.lemonde.fr/proche-orient/article/2017/10/26/en-syrie-les-faubourgs-rebelles-de-damas-affames_5206154_3218.html| publisher=[[Le Monde]]| date=26 October 2017| author=Madjid Zerrouky| accessdate=15 March 2018}}
105,000{{cite news| title=Over 105,000 civilians have fled Syria's Eastern Ghouta |publisher=France24| url=http://www.france24.com/en/20180324-syria-eastern-ghouta-civilians-fled-rebels-militants|date=24 March 2018| accessdate=25 March 2018}}–140,000 displaced (2018) | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Syrian uprising}} {{Campaignbox Rif Dimashq Campaign}} }} The '''Siege of Eastern Ghouta''' was a siege that was laid by [[Council of Ministers (Syria)|Syrian Government]] forces in April 2013,{{cite web|title=Report of the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on the Syrian Arab Republic—Thirty-seventh session |url=http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/HRBodies/HRCouncil/CoISyria/A-HRC-37-72_EN.pdf|publisher=United Nations Human Rights Council|page=20—25|date=1 February 2018|accessdate=22 February 2018}} to the area in eastern [[Ghouta]] held by [[Syrian rebels|anti-government forces]] since November 2012, during the [[Syrian Civil War]]. The cities and villages under siege were [[Douma, Syria|Douma]], [[Mesraba]], [[Arbin, Syria|Arbin]], [[Hamouria]], [[Saqba]], Modira, Eftreis, Jisrin, as well as suburbs of [[Damascus]] [[Beit Sawa]], [[Harasta]], [[Zamalka]], [[Ein Tarma]] and [[Kafr Batna]].{{cite news|title=Eastern Ghouta Syria: The neighbourhoods below the bombs|date=2 March 2018| publisher=BBC News| url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-43154146| accessdate=13 March 2018}} By 2016, around 400,000 people were trapped in an area just over 100 [[square kilometre]]s in size,{{cite news|title=The unravelling of Syria's Eastern Ghouta|author=Tom Rollins|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/12/unravelling-syria-eastern-ghouta-161204082727105.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=18 December 2016|accessdate=22 February 2018}} thus with a [[population density]] around 4,000 hab./km². [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 2401]], adopted on 28 February 2018, called for a nationwide ceasefire in Syria for 30 days, including Eastern Ghouta, but the [[Syrian Army]] continued the offensive. In March 2018, the Syrian Army split the enclave into three parts, reaching an agreement with the rebels to withdraw to the north, to [[Idlib]]. This action displaced 105,000 people from the area. Douma was the only city left by the end of that month that was not under Syrian government control. On 8 April 2018, an agreement had been reached to evacuate remaining fighters and civilians from the last rebel-controlled pocket of [[Douma, Syria|Douma]] after an alleged [[2018 Douma chemical attack|chemical weapons attack]] that reportedly killed 70 people.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/08/middleeast/syria-chemical-attack-douma-intl/index.html|title=Syria claims it wasn't behind Saturday's chemical attack, but others disagree|last=CNN|first=Sheena McKenzie, Tamara Qiblawi and Fred Pleitgen,|work=CNN|access-date=2018-04-08}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=12028670|title=The Latest: Russia says deal struck for rebels to exit Douma|date=2018-04-08|work=NZ Herald|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777}}[https://news.sky.com/story/syrian-opposition-and-russia-reach-agreement-over-douma-11323228 Syrian opposition and Russia reach agreement over Douma] Sky News, 08 April 2018 The Syrian Government denied responsibility, together with its ally involved in the war, Russia. More than 50,000 people, including fighters from the [[Jaysh al-Islam|Jaish al-Islam]] and their families, have been evacuated out of the city as part of the deal, to northern Syria.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-ghouta/syrian-rebels-evacuated-from-douma-reach-northwest-monitor-idUSKBN1HH19M|title=Syrian rebels evacuated from Douma reach northwest: monitor|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-US}} Around 200 hostages loyal to the Syrian Government have reportedly been released by the rebels. Russian military police were deployed to [[Douma, Syria|Douma]] to enforce the agreement.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-douma/scores-of-rebels-hostages-leave-syrias-douma-under-deal-state-media-idUSKBN1HG32C|title=Scores of rebels, hostages leave Syria's Douma under deal: state media|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-US}} Thousands of people were killed during this 5-year siege period. Numerous [[war crimes]] allegations were made during the siege, among others from the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]], including the use of prohibited weapons, attacks on civilians, attacks against protected objects (schools, hospitals), [[starvation]] as a method of warfare and denial of [[medical evacuation]]. ==Background== {{see also|Rif Dimashq Governorate campaign|Battle of Douma}} Prior to the [[Syrian Civil War]], the total population of Eastern [[Ghouta]], a collection of farms and cities near [[Damascus]], was around 1.5 million people. During the [[Civil uprising phase of the Syrian Civil War|civil unrest]] that began in Syria in March 2011, some of the eastern Ghouta residents took part in the protests against the Syrian president [[Bashar Al-Assad]] and joined the [[Syrian rebels]] and [[Rif Dimashq offensive (November 2012–February 2013)|expelled Syrian government forces]] by November 2012.{{cite news|title=Living Under Assad’s Siege|publisher=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/07/opinion/syria-bombing-assad.html| date=7 February 2018|author=Yassin Al-Haj Saleh}} In February 2013, Syrian rebels [[Damascus offensive (2013)|captured]] parts of the ring road on the edge of Damascus and entered the [[Jobar|Jobar district]] of the capital city.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/11/world/middleeast/syrian-war-closes-in-on-the-heart-of-damascus.html?pagewanted=1&pagewanted=print | title=Damascus on Edge as War Seeps into Syrian Capital | work=New York Times | date=10 February 2013}} Backed by [[Iran]] and [[Hezbollah]], the [[Syrian Arab Army]] counterattacked and in April 2013 began a siege of Eastern Ghouta, which is just 15 km or a half hour's drive outside the capital Damascus.{{cite web| title=Syria: Children Under Attack in Damascus Enclave: UN Security Council Should Act on Eastern Ghouta Situation | publisher=Human Rights Watch| url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/01/11/syria-children-under-attack-damascus-enclave| date=11 January 2018| accessdate=25 February 2018}} Cut off from the rest of the country, the population of Eastern Ghouta resorted to [[incineration of plastics]] to generate electricity. In early 2015, when the Syrian government cut off water supplies to [[Duma, Syria|Duma]], the population adapted yet again and dug over 600 underground wells, using manual pumps to supply water. ==History== {{see also|Rif Dimashq offensive (August–November 2014)|Rif Dimashq offensive (September 2015)|Rif Dimashq offensive (June–October 2016)|East Ghouta inter-rebel conflict (April–May 2017)|Rif Dimashq offensive (February–April 2018)}} [[File:Ghouta Juin 2017.svg|thumb|Map of the Eastern Ghouta enclave in 2017 {{leftlegend|#EDC4BE|Syrian Government control}}{{leftlegend|#CDEBC9|Opposition control}}|left]] In mid-2017, the main rebel faction in the area was [[Jaysh al-Islam]], based in [[Douma, Syria|Douma]] (with an estimated 10-15,000 fighters in the region in early 2018[http://www.dw.com/en/which-rebel-groups-are-fighting-in-syrias-eastern-ghouta/a-42663501 Which rebel groups are fighting in Syria's eastern Ghouta?], Deutsche Welle, 20.02.2018). The second largest was [[Faylaq al-Rahman]], an official affiliate of the [[Free Syrian Army]] (FSA), controlling much of central and western parts of Ghouta, including the [[Jobar]] and [[Ain Terma]] districts. [[Ahrar al-Sham]] (based in [[Harasta]]) and [[Tahrir al-Sham]] (HTS - controlling smaller districts such as [[Arbin, Syria|Arbin]], [[al-Ashari]] and Bait Naim, with an estimated strength in the area of 500 in February 2018[https://monitoring.bbc.co.uk/product/c1douzrw Explainer: Who's fighting whom in Syria's Ghouta?], BBC Monitoring, 22 February 2018) had a far smaller presence.Wisam Franjieh [https://www.newsdeeply.com/syria/articles/2017/08/01/in-besieged-eastern-ghouta-rebel-infighting-increases-civilian-suffering In Besieged Eastern Ghouta, Rebel Infighting Increases Civilian Suffering], Syria Deeply, Aug. 1, 2017 In August 2013, the area was subjected to a [[Ghouta chemical attack|chemical attack]] that killed hundreds of people,{{cite web|title=‘Clear and convincing’ evidence of chemical weapons use in Syria. UN team reports|accessdate=22 February 2018|date=16 September 2013|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2013/09/449052-clear-and-convincing-evidence-chemical-weapons-use-syria-un-team-reports|publisher=United Nations News}} after which an agreement was made to ban chemical weapons in Syria. From 14 to 30 November 2017, the Russian-Syrian forces conducted more than 400 airstrikes in the area, hitting markets, schools and houses, and during some of those airstrikes allegedly using banned [[cluster munition]].{{cite web|title=Syria/Russia: Airstrikes, Siege Killing Civilians: Allow Urgent Aid into Besieged Eastern Ghouta and End Indiscriminate Attacks| publisher=Human Rights Watch| date= 22 December 2017| url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/12/22/syria/russia-airstrikes-siege-killing-civilians| accessdate=25 February 2018}} Despite efforts at turning Ghouta into a [[Safe Zone (Syria)|de-escalation zone]], reports of bombs allegedly containing weaponised [[chlorine]] were registered again in early 2018.{{cite web|title=Syria: UN urges an end to hostilities, warns of grave and deepening humanitarian crisis|accessdate=22 February 2018|date=6 February 2018|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/02/1002071|publisher=United Nations News}} By January 2018, the area had only a single doctor per 3,600 people.{{cite journal|title=Syria: 7 years into a civil war|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(18)30006-0|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673618300060 |journal=[[The Lancet]]|volume= 391|issue= 10115|date= 12 January 2018|p=15–16|author=Sharmila Devi}} [[East Ghouta inter-rebel conflict (April–May 2016)|Inter-rebel fighting in 2016]] and [[East Ghouta inter-rebel conflict (April–May 2017)|once again in 2017]] deteriorated the situation even further, showing a lack of unity among the rebel groups. [[File:Ghouta Marj Jaysh al-Islam 13-2-2017(3).jpg|thumb|Jaysh al-Islam rebels in Eastern Ghouta in February 2017|left]] After a series of [[Battle of Harasta (2017–18)|offensive operations]] launched by [[Syrian rebel]]s against positions of the [[Syrian Arab Army]] in [[Harasta]], a northeastern suburb of [[Damascus]], and other locations in Ghouta, the Syrian Arab Army launched an [[Rif Dimashq offensive (February 2018)|operation]] to capture the rebel-held part of Ghouta in February 2018. The escalation of hostilities led to a [[United Nations Security Council]] meeting held on 24 February 2018, voting unanimously in favor of a 30-day cease-fire in Syria, and demanded immediate lifting of the siege of eastern Ghouta.{{cite web|title=UN Security Council agrees 30-day ceasefire in Syria |url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/02/1003501|date=24 February 2018|accessdate=25 February 2018|publisher=United Nations News}} In March 2018 the government offensive continued, being supported by the Russia both diplomatically and militarily.[https://www.rferl.org/a/syria-russia-vows-back-assad-vs-terror-threat-ghouta-bloodshed/29067479.html Amid Outcry Over Ghouta, Russia Vows To Back Assad Against 'Terror Threat'] Radio Liberty, 28 February 2018.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-ghouta/assad-vows-to-press-ghouta-assault-as-civilians-flee-government-advances-idUSKBN1GG09E Assad vows to press Ghouta assault, as civilians flee government advances] Reuters, 4 March 2018. On 11 March, the Syrian government took control over several areas and split the enclave into three pockets.{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-ghouta/syrian-army-splinters-rebel-enclave-in-ghouta-onslaught-idUSKCN1GN095|publisher=Reuters|date=11 March 2018|title=Syrian army splinters rebel enclave in Ghouta onslaught| accessdate=13 March 2018}} These pockets include [[Douma, Syria|Duma]] and its northeastern outskirts, eastern [[Harasta]], and [[Zamalka]] and surrounding area.{{Cite web|url=http://syria.liveuamap.com/en/2018/11-march-syrian-arab-army-captures-madraya-town-begins-sweeping|title=Syrian Arab Army captures Madraya town, begins sweeping operations, East Ghouta is in 2 and almost parts with progress on Harasta front - Map of Syrian Civil War - Syria news today - syria.liveuamap.com|website=Map of Syrian Civil War - Syria news today - syria.liveuamap.com|language=en|access-date=2018-03-12}} In mid-late March after a series of negotiations, a deal was finally reached between the Syrian government and rebels that controlled parts of Eastern Ghouta. The deal involved a transfer of remaining rebel fighters from the areas of eastern [[Harasta]], [[Zamalka]] and surrounding areas to the province of Idlib. 105,000 people were displaced by this evacuation from the area. By the end of March, [[Douma, Syria|Douma]] was the last pocket controlled by the rebels, the Jaish al-Islam fighters.{{cite web|title=Syrian army command says it has regained most of eastern Ghouta| publisher=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-ghouta/syrian-army-command-says-it-has-regained-most-of-eastern-ghouta-idUSKBN1H70IX| date=31 March 2018| accessdate=1 April 2018}} For at least 10 days, there were minimal attacks on the rebel pocket of Douma as talks with the Jaish al-Islam continued. It was reported later that the Jaish al-Islam shelled residential areas in [[Damascus]], causing casualties and material damage. By 6 April, talks had "faltered" between the two sides and the [[Syrian Army|SAA]] renewed their offensive in response to the attack. The [[Jaysh al-Islam|Jaish al-Islam]] denied responsibility.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/04/syrian-forces-press-offernsive-rebel-held-douma-180407135235699.html|title=Syrian forces press ahead with offensive in rebel-held Douma|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-04-07}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-43674329|title=Syrian warplanes strike rebel enclave|date=2018-04-06|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-04-07|language=en-GB}} The rebel group had also reportedly refused to release detainees loyal to the Syrian government it was holding in [[Douma, Syria|Douma]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/fresh-raids-pound-syria-s-rebel-douma-after-talks-falter-10114666|title=Fresh raids pound Syria's rebel Douma after talks falter|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=2018-04-07|language=en-US}} The shelling on 8 April 2018, which left several civilians dead, [[Douma chemical attack|drew allegations of chemical weapons use in Douma]], though the UN could not verify the claim initially.{{Cite news|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/04/1006801 | title=Amid allegations of chemical weapons use in Douma, UN chief calls for civilian protection| date=8 April 2018| publisher=UN News| accessdate=8 April 2018}} ==Casualties== In February 2018, the [[Syrian Network for Human Rights]], a UK-based non-governmental organization, founded in June 2011, published a report alleging that 12,783 civilians were killed in and around Eastern Ghouta from March 2011 to February 2018, including 1,463 children and 1,127 women. According to local hospital sources, which were cited in the French newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]'', approximately 18,000 people were killed in the enclave by October 2017. [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] claimed that 70 percent of the enclave's population lived underground by November 2017 to escape bombardments. It also registered that, on average, 71 people were being killed daily since the 18 February 2018 offensive. It registered 1,005 people killed and 4,829 wounded in two weeks alone, between 18 February and 3 March 2018.{{cite news|url=http://www.msf.org/en/article/syria-outrageous-relentless-mass-casualty-disaster-east-ghouta|title=Syria: An outrageous, relentless mass casualty disaster in East Ghouta|date=8 March 2018|publisher=Médecins Sans Frontières}} ==War crimes allegations== === Government and allies === Numerous [[war crimes]] allegations were made during the battle, including the use of prohibited weapons, attacks on civilians, attacks against protected objects (schools, hospitals), [[starvation]] as a method of warfare and denial of [[medical evacuation]]. The siege by the [[Syrian Government|Syrian government]] left the enclave under a humanitarian crisis, leading to [[famine]] and a lack of food.{{cite web|title=Syria: UN urges an end to hostilities, warns of grave and deepening humanitarian crisis|accessdate=22 February 2018|date=6 February 2018|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/02/1002071|publisher=United Nations News}}{{cite web|title='At the doors of starvation:' siege strangles Damascus suburbs|accessdate=22 February 2018|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-ghouta/at-the-doors-of-starvation-siege-strangles-damascus-suburbs-idUSKBN1CW003|date=27 October 2017|publisher=Reuters}}{{cite web|title=Syria: Suffering in Eastern Ghouta reaches “critical point” | date=18 December 2017| publisher=International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC)| url=https://www.icrc.org/en/document/syria-suffering-eastern-ghouta-reaches-critical-point |accessdate=27 February 2018}} According to a 2014 [[United Nations]] report, the denial of food as a military strategy began during July and August 2013: Eastern Ghouta's crops and farms were shelled and burned. The report also alleged that Syrian forces "blocked access roads and systematically confiscated food, fuel and medicine at checkpoints". Some inhabitants had to rely on tree leaves as an alternative for vegetables to survive. The rebels established a web of underground tunnels to smuggle supplies, but they were destroyed by the government forces.{{cite web|title=With tunnel lifeline cut, pressure mounts on Syrian rebel enclave|date =11 May 2017| publisher=Reuters|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-mideast-crisis-syria-ghouta/with-tunnel-lifeline-cut-pressure-mounts-on-syrian-rebel-enclave-idUKKBN1872QK| accessdate=25 February 2018}} [[File:Karim Abdallah 2017.jpg|thumb|A child casualty on 29 October 2017|left]] [[UNICEF]] Representatives said that at least 12% of children under 5 were acutely [[Malnourishment|malnourished]] in the enclave in early 2018.{{cite web|title=120 children need urgent medical evacuation from East Ghouta|accessdate=22 February 2018|url=https://news.un.org/en/audio/2018/01/1000672|date=17 January 2018|publisher=United Nations News}} On 27 October 2017, the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]], [[Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein]], warned that "the deliberate starvation of civilians as a method of warfare constitutes a clear violation of international humanitarian law" and called for access of humanitarian workers to deliver aid to the people of Eastern Ghouta.{{cite web|title=Syria: Suffering of civilians in Eastern Ghouta “an outrage” – Zeid|publisher=United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=22312|date=27 October 2017|accessdate=23 February 2018}} The Syrian government restricted humanitarian aid to the enclave. On 30 October 2017, supplies were allowed to only 40,000 residents in the two cities of [[Kafr Batna]] and [[Saqba]]. One U.N. aid convoy arrived to Eastern Ghouta in February 2018, only after it had no access for 78 days.{{cite web|title=UN, partners complete first aid delivery in months to Syria’s war-battered east Ghouta|accessdate=22 February 2018|date=14 February 2018|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/02/1002911|publisher=United Nations News}} [[File:Ghouta massacre4.JPG|thumb|Corpses of the victims of the [[Ghouta chemical attack|2013 chemical attack]]]] [[Use of chemical weapons in the Syrian Civil War|The Syrian government also used chemical weapons]] against the armed groups in Eastern Ghouta in July 2017, specifically in [[Ein Tarma]] (1 July{{cite web|title=Report of the Independent International Commission of Inquiry on the Syrian Arab Republic|url=http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/HRBodies/HRCouncil/CoISyria/A_HRC_36_55_EN.docx |publisher=United Nations Human Rights Council—Thirty-sixth session|page=15|date=8 August 2017|accessdate=8 April 2018}}), [[Zamalka]] (2 July) and [[Jobar]] (6 July), and on [[Harasta]] on 18 November 2017. The agents included [[chlorine gas]] and [[organophosphorous]] [[pesticide]]. The Syrian government also used internationally banned [[incendiary weapons]]. In one such incident reported on 16 March 2018, at 11:48am, these weapons were dropped on Kafr Batna, killing at least 61 and wounding over 200 people.{{cite web|title=Russia Backs Syria in Unlawful Attacks on Eastern Ghouta| url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/03/18/russia-backs-syria-unlawful-attacks-eastern-ghouta| publisher=Human Rights Watch| date=18 March 2018| accessdate=25 March 2018}} In December 2017, satellite imagery analysis by [[United Nations|UN]] experts concluded that 3,853 buildings were destroyed, 5,141 severely damaged and 3,547 moderately damaged in the western parts of the enclave. The suburb of [[Jobar]] was 93 % destroyed, [[Ein Tarma]] 73 % and [[Zamalka]] 59 %.{{cite news|title=Syria war: Families struggle to survive in Eastern Ghouta, under siege|date=22 February 2018|publisher=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-43148010|accessdate=23 February 2018}} Hospitals in Eastern Ghouta were reported to have been shelled: Syrian army forces destroyed a field hospital in Al-Zemaniyah during a [[Rif Dimashq offensive (March–August 2013)#Battle for the suburbs|ground operation]] in July 2013, while shells landed near Al-Fatih hospital, where victims of the chemical attack were treated, forcing it to discharge its patients.{{cite web|url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/HRC/RegularSessions/Session25/Documents/A-HRC-25-65_en.doc| title=Report of the independent international commission of inquiry on the Syrian Arab Republic |date=12 February 2014 |p=16, 20| publisher=United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights| accessdate=25 February 2018}} Between 4 and 21 February 2018, the Syrian-Russian bombardments killed 346 people in Eastern Ghouta.{{cite web|title=UN chief ‘deeply alarmed’ by escalating hostilities in Syria’s east Ghouta|accessdate=22 February 2018|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/02/1003161|date=21 February 2018|publisher=United Nations News}} Local counts reported 700 deaths in the three months up to mid-February 2018, many of them civilians.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/20/its-not-a-war-its-a-massacre-scores-killed-in-syrian-enclave-eastern-ghouta 'It's not a war. It's a massacre': scores killed in Syrian enclave], Guardian, 20 February 2018 On 7 December 2017, the United Nations Senior Advisor [[Jan Egeland]] called east Ghouta the "epicenter of suffering".{{cite web|title=Note to Correspondents: Joint Press Stakeout by UN Special Envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, and UN Senior Advisor Jan Egelan |url=https://www.un.org/sg/en/content/sg/note-correspondents/2017-12-07/note-correspondents-joint-press-stakeout-un-special-envoy|date=7 December 2017|accessdate=22 February 2018|publisher=United Nations}} After the end of the siege, tens of thousands of people have been unlawfully [[Internment|interned]] by the Syrian Government forces in rural Damascus, including Ghouta.{{cite web| title=Siege of Syria’s eastern Ghouta ‘barbaric and medieval’, says UN Commission of Inquiry| date=20 June 2018| publisher=UN News|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/06/1012632|accessdate=22 June 2018}} [[Amnesty International]] has called the "unlawful siege and unlawful killing of civilians, including the use of internationally banned cluster munitions" by the Syrian government and Russia a war crime and a [[crime against humanity]].{{cite web|title=Syria: Relentless bombing of civilians in Eastern Ghouta amounts to war crimes|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2018/02/syria-relentless-bombing-of-civilians-in-eastern-ghouta-amounts-to-war-crimes/|publisher=Amnesty International|date=20 February 2018|accessdate=22 February 2018}} === Rebel groups === The United Nations also found the four largest rebel factions that were active in eastern Ghouta, namely [[Jaysh al-Islam]], the [[Al-Rahman Legion]], [[Ahrar al-Sham]], and [[Tahrir al-Sham]], guilty of crimes against humanity. They were known to arrest and torture members of religious minority groups, and regularly fired [[mortar (weapon)|mortar]]s and rockets from eastern Ghouta at government-held areas. These attacks aimed at spreading terror, and killed many civilians.{{cite web| title=Stop the “monstrous annihilation” of Eastern Ghouta – Zeid| url=http://www.ohchr.org/EN/NewsEvents/Pages/Media.aspx |location=Geneva| date=21 February 2018| publisher=United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights| accessdate=25 February 2018}}{{cite news| title=Intense mortar shelling kills 5 in Syria's Damascus| publisher=Xinhuanet| url=http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-02/20/c_136987401.htm |date=20 February 2018| accessdate=27 February 2018}} ==Reactions== ===United Nations=== {{See also|UN investigation of chemical weapons use in Ghouta}} 2013: After the alleged [[Ghouta chemical attack|chemical weapons attack]] in the Ghouta area of Damascus, the [[United Nations|UN]] sent an inspection team to begin an investigation. The final report concluded that evidence suggests that "surface-to-surface rockets containing the nerve agent sarin were used in Ein Tarma, Moadamiyah and Zamalka". The Russian government dismissed the initial UN report after it was released, calling it "one-sided" and "distorted".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/19/world/middleeast/syria.html|title=Russia Calls U.N. Chemical Report on Syria Biased|last=Myers|first=Steven Lee|date=2013-09-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-03-15|last2=Gladstone|first2=Rick|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} 2018: After the start of the renewed [[Syrian Army|SAA]] offensive called "[[Rif Dimashq offensive (February 2018–present)|Rif Dimashq offensive]]" during mid-February, the [[United Nations|UN]] proposed a 30-day ceasefire aimed at allowing aid deliveries to enter besieged areas, as well as medical evacuations.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-43183903|title=UN approves 30-day ceasefire in Syria|date=2018-02-25|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-15|language=en-GB}} This ceasefire was "ignored" as the [[Syrian Army|SAA]] continued its advances into the rebel-controlled areas. It was reported that in the following month, some 25 food trucks were allowed in. Some argued that this was simply not enough for the people living in war-torn areas.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/03/limited-food-allowed-enter-syria-besieged-eastern-ghouta-180315094808111.html|title=Limited food allowed to enter Syria's besieged Eastern Ghouta|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2018-03-15}} ===USA, France, UK=== {{See also|2018 bombing of Damascus and Homs}} The governments of the United States, [[United Kingdom]] and [[France]] accused the Syrian government of a [[2018 Douma chemical attack|chemical attack against the population of Douma]] on April 2018. As a consequence, the three states conducted a series of airstrikes targeting sites associated with Syria's chemical weapons capabilities in Damascus and Homs on 14 April 2018. {{Cite web|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/04/1007331| date=14 April 2018| publisher=UN News| title=Following airstrikes, UN chief warns against escalation over Syria}} The next day, Russia tried to pass a resolution condemning these US-UK-French airstrikes, but it was not adopted by the U.N. Security Council.{{Cite web|url=https://news.un.org/en/story/2018/04/1007341| date=15 April 2018| publisher=UN News| title=Security Council rejects Russian request to condemn airstrikes in Syria}} ==Gallery== White Helmets Arbin 6-2-2018.jpg|[[White Helmets (Syrian Civil War)|White Helmets]] looking for survivors in [[Arbin, Syria|Arbin]] Ghouta 22-2-2018 (2).jpg|Aerial bombardments of East Ghouta in February 2018 Ghouta Arbin 27-2-2018 (4).jpg|Ruins in Arbin on 27 February 2018 Ghouta Arbin 27-2-2018 (2).jpg|A family in Ghouta on 28 February 2018 Ghouta Arbin 27-2-2018 (1).jpg|Streets of Arbin in 2018 ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{portal|Syrian civil war}} *[https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde24/2079/2015/en/ Syria: Left to Die Under Siege] [[Amnesty International]] report in 2015 {{Syrian civil war}} {{coord missing|Syria}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eastern Ghouta, Siege of}} [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War in 2013]] [[Category:Rif Dimashq Governorate in the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Crimes against humanity]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Syrian government]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving Hezbollah]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving the Free Syrian Army]] [[Category:Sieges of the Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Syrian Civil War crimes]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2013]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2014]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2015]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2016]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2017]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2018]] [[Category:Russian war crimes]] [[Category:Military operations of the Syrian Civil War involving chemical weapons]]

''Metal Gear'' | allegiance ={{PAK}} | branch =[[File:Naval Jack of Pakistan.svg|20px]] [[Pakistan Navy]] | serviceyears =1948–1986 | rank =[[File:US-O10 insignia.svg|30px]][[File:Admiral Pakistan Navy Insignia.JPG|10px]] [[Admiral]] | unit =[[Pakistan Navy#Branches|Surface Branch]] | commands =[[Chief of Staff of Pakistan Navy|Vice-Chief of Naval Staff]]

[[Naval attaché]] [[High Commission of Pakistan, London|Pakistan Embassy, London]] | battles =[[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965]]
[[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971]] *[[Bangladesh Liberation War]] | mawards =[[File:Order of Excellence Nishan-e-Imtiaz.png|30px]] [[Nishan-e-Imtiaz]]
[[File:Star of Excellence Sitara-e-Imtiaz.png|30px]] [[Sitara-e-Imtiaz]]
[[File:Star of Good Conduct Sitara-e-Basalat.png|30px]] [[Sitara-e-Basalat]] | military_blank1 = | military_data1 = | military_blank2 = | military_data2 = | military_blank3 = | military_data3 = | military_blank4 = | military_data4 = | military_blank5 = | military_data5 = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | footnotes = }} [[Admiral]] '''Tariq Kamal Khan''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|طارق کمال خان}}}}; b. 21 May 1930), {{small|[[Nishan-e-Imtiaz|NI(M)]], [[Sitara-e-Imtiaz|SI(M)]], [[Sitara-e-Basalat|SBt]]}}, is a retired [[four-star rank|four-star]] rank [[Four star admiral|admiral]] and a former [[diplomat]] who served as a [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Naval Staff (CNS)]] of [[Pakistan Navy]] from being appointed in 1983 until retiring from his [[Military service|service]] in 1986.{{rp|199}}{{cite book|last1=Cheema|first1=Pervaiz Iqbal|authorlink1=Pervaiz Iqbal Cheema|title=The Armed Forces of Pakistan|date=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford, uk|isbn=0195798392|pages=220|edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cw_gduyRv5oC&pg=PA199&dq=tariq+kamal+khan+armed+forces+of+pakistan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjeyZe07ejRAhUN8WMKHRtLClwQ6wEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=tariq%20kamal%20khan%20armed%20forces%20of%20pakistan&f=false|accessdate=30 January 2017|language=en|format=googlebooks}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.chowrangi.com/alexander-naval-station.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2009-11-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604101736/http://www.chowrangi.com/alexander-naval-station.html |archive-date=2011-06-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}http://chr.sagepub.com/cgi/pdf_extract/21/1/95https://www.flickr.com/photos/pimu/864111636/http://www.mabaig.co.uk/paf/Squadrons/8.html Prior to that, he was appointed as the [[List of diplomatic missions of Pakistan|High Commissioner of Pakistan]] to [[Australia]] and served from 1986 until 1992 when he retired from the foreign service.{{rp|352}}{{cite book|last1=GoP|first1=Govt. of Pakistan|title=Statistical Pocket-book of Pakistan|date=1992|publisher=Manager of Publications|location=Islamabad Pakistan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UOAXT7lXoecC&dq=tariq+kamal+khan+ambassador&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=tariq+kamal+khan|accessdate=30 January 2017}} ==Biography== ===Naval Career and star appointments=== Tariq Kamal Khan was born in [[Jhelum]], [[British Punjab|Punjab]], [[British Indian Empire|British India]] into a [[Pathans of Punjab|Punjabi-Pathan]] family on 21 May 1930.{{cite web|last1=Pakistani connections|first1=pc|title=پاک بحریہ کے سربراہ۔ ایڈمرل طارق کمال خان|url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:6ckVjtN0GI0J:www.pakistanconnections.com/history/index/2015-03-23/2204+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us|website=www.pakistanconnections.com|publisher=Pakistani connections|accessdate=30 January 2017}} After graduating from a local high school, he was [[Commissioned officer|commissioned]] as [[Midshipman]] in the [[Pakistan Navy]] in 1948 in [[Pakistan Navy#Branches|Surface warfare branch]] and was initially trained at the [[Pakistan Military Academy]]. He was later trained in the [[United Kingdom]] as a [[Signals intelligence|communication]] specialist and as the [[Surface warfare insignia|surface warfare]] officer and promoted as [[Sub lieutenant|Sub-Lieutenant]] after returning to Pakistan. His further military training came from the [[Britannia Royal Naval College]] in [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]], [[England]] and did qualified on courses on [[military communications]]. In 1965, [[Lieutenant (naval)|Lieutenant]] TK Khan participated in [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|second war]] with [[India]] and served on [[PNS Shah Jahan (DD-962)|PNS Shah Jahan]] as its [[executive officer]] while taking part on [[Operation Dwarka|naval shelling]] in [[Dwarka]], [[India]]. In 1969, he was promoted as [[Lieutenant-Commander]] and [[Commander (rank)|Commander]] after posting in [[East Pakistan]] as [[commanding officer]] of {{ship|PNS|Jahangir||2}}.{{rp|xxx}}{{cite book|last1=Cardozo|first1=Major General Ian|title=The Sinking of INS Khukri: Survivor's Stories|publisher=Roli Books Private Limited|isbn=9789351940999|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xvs_CgAAQBAJ&pg=PT161&dq=Admiral+TK+Khan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiy6Zmx6-jRAhUS2WMKHRHVCXU4ChC7BQgmMAI#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=30 January 2017|language=en}} [[Commander (rank)|Cdr]] TK Khan also helped the [[Pakistan Army]] with the communication gears and firing at the [[East Pakistan Rifles]] headquarters to crush Bengali resistance in Chittagong area.{{cite web|last1=Hussain|first1=Khadim|title=The Way It Was - 2|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/sept98/wayitwas2.htm|website=www.defencejournal.com|publisher=Defence Journal. 1998|accessdate=30 January 2017|language=en|date=September 1998}}[http://www.bdsdf.org/forum/index.php?showtopic=3588&st=60 See Navy Officers] [[Commander (rank)|Cdr]] Khan participated on various military [[Riverine Warfare|riverine missions]] while commanding a [[gunboat]], ''Jahangir'', and was taken [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 Prisoners of War Investigation|war prisoner]] after the [[Instrument of Surrender (1971)|accessioning the surrender]] with [[India]] in 1971. He was [[Delhi Agreement|repatriated]] to Pakistan and continue resuming his military service when he was promoted as [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] in the Navy. From 1975–1978, Captain Khan was posted in the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Pakistan)|Foreign ministry]] to be served as [[naval attaché]] to the [[High Commission of Pakistan, London|Pakistan High Commission]] in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]].{{rp|564}}{{cite book|last1=Copley|first1=Gregory R.|title=Defense & Foreign Affairs Handbook|date=1975|publisher=Perth Corporation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bnPfAAAAMAAJ&dq=captain+tariq+kamal+khan&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=tariq+kamal|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en}}{{cite web|title=Excepts|url=https://books.google.com/books/content?id=bnPfAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA564&img=1&pgis=1&dq=tariq+kamal&sig=ACfU3U1LPHvwhlcuvH9LXRzJExdzYrMgow&edge=0|accessdate=31 January 2017}} Upon returning to Pakistan, he was promoted to one-star rank, [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]] and posted in Karachi for a command assignment in 1978. [[Commodore (rank)|Cdre]] Khan commanded the 18th Destroyer Squadron as its [[officer commanding]] until 1980 after promoting as [[Rear-Admiral]].{{rp|151}}{{cite book|last1=Sirohey|first1=Iftikhar Ahmed|authorlink1=Iftikhar Ahmed Sirohey|title=Truth Never Retires: An Autobiography of Admiral Iftikhar Ahmed Sirohey|date=1995|publisher=Jang Publishers|location=Karachi Pakistan|isbn=978-969-8500-00-9|pages=592|edition=1|language=en}} ===Chief of Naval Staff=== [[Rear-Admiral]] Khan was appointed [[Pakistan Navy#Commands|Commander Karachi]] (COMKAR) until 1983 when he succeeded Admiral [[Karamat Rahman Niazi|K.R. Niazi]] as Chief of Naval Staff.{{rp|278}}{{rp|241}}{{cite book|title=News Review on South Asia and Indian Ocean|publisher=Institute for Defence Studies & Analyses.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HY4gAQAAMAAJ&dq=Tariq+Kamal+Khan++rear+admiral&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Tariq+Kamal+Khan|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en}} On 22 March 1983, [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|Zia-ul-Haq]] announced to appoint Rear-Admiral Khan as the [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Naval Staff]] but this promotion came with controversy.{{rp|194}}{{cite book|last1=Noman|first1=Omar|title=Pakistan|date=1988|publisher=Routledge|location=New York, U.S.|isbn=9781136143946|pages=230|edition=1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BfKzAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA194&dq=admiral+tariq+kamal+khan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYicj34OvRAhVFjFQKHZkbB7YQ6wEIMjAE#v=onepage&q=admiral%20tariq%20kamal%20khan&f=false|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en|format=googlebooks|chapter=Ethnic Conflict}}{{cite book|title=Excerpts-II|url=https://books.google.com/books/content?id=-IHjAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA278&img=1&pgis=1&dq=one+Vice+Admiral+and+two+Rear+Admirals&sig=ACfU3U1LpYVF5obnWpS1Bys3kH4Ofa5v8w&edge=0|accessdate=31 January 2017}} Rear-Admiral TK Khan, a junior admiral, supersedes the most senior [[Vice-Admiral]] [[Iqbal F. Qadir|Iqbal Quadir]] and two senior Rear-Admirals for the command of the Navy in 1983.{{rp|278–279}} Rear-Admiral TK Khan was known to be close to President Zia and had experience in military administration in civil affairs from the East Pakistan, that may have been a factor for his appointment to the four-star appointment.{{rp|277}} After his appointment was announced, Rear-Admiral Tariq Kamal Khan was appointed as [[four-star rank|four-star]] rank [[admiral]] in the Navy.{{rp|278}} In 1983, he helped negotiated the acquisition of [[Mirage V]] aircraft from [[France]] for the [[Pakistan Air Force]] when he traveled to [[Paris]], France.{{rp|159}}{{cite book|title=Near East/South Asia Report|date=1983|publisher=Foreign Broadcast Information Service|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dSu6AAAAIAAJ&q=commodore+tariq+kamal&dq=commodore+tariq+kamal&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjs5sDkyevRAhVGjVQKHTSQBnAQ6wEIJjAC|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en}} As [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|naval chief]], Admiral TK Khan began initiating a program to acquire and procure modern warships to replace and scrap the aging warships in service with the Navy.{{rp|109}}{{cite book|title=Near East/South Asia Report|publisher=Foreign Broadcast Information Service|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SCm6AAAAIAAJ&q=admiral+tariq+kamal+khan&dq=admiral+tariq+kamal+khan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYicj34OvRAhVFjFQKHZkbB7YQ6wEIQDAH|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en}} Admiral Tariq Kamal worked closely towards strengthening [[China–Pakistan relations|bilateral relations]] between [[China]] and [[Pakistan]], briefly meeting with [[President of the People's Republic of China|Chinese President]] [[Li Xiannian]] for that purpose in 1984.{{rp|44}}{{cite book|title=Beijing Review|publisher=Beijing Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M1moq8As76oC&q=admiral+tariq+kamal+khan&dq=admiral+tariq+kamal+khan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjUjIa_4uvRAhUhr1QKHdq7A8M4FBDrAQgaMAA|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en}} Admiral Tariq Kamal Khan remained [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|naval chief]] until [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|naval chief]] he sought retirement from his active service and handed over the command to his [[Vice Chief of Naval Staff (India)|VCNS]], [[Vice-Admiral]] [[Iftikhar Ahmed Sirohey]].{{rp|51–52}}{{cite book|title=Pakistan & Gulf Economist|publisher=Economist Publications|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DQ-ZvVNKGfsC&dq=admiral+tariq+kamal+khan+retired&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Sirohey|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en}} ===Ambassadorship and later life=== After his retirement from Navy, Admiral Khan joined the [[Foreign Service of Pakistan|Foreign Service]] when he was nominated to be appointed as [[List of diplomatic missions of Pakistan|High Commissioner of Pakistan]] to [[Australia]] by [[Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq|President Zia]] and served from 1986 until 1992 when he retired from the foreign service.{{rp|352}} During his tenure as [[List of diplomatic missions of Pakistan|High Commissioner]], he helped secure the deal of second-hand and [[Royal Australian Air Force]]'s retired [[Dassault Mirage III]] to be inducted in the service with [[Pakistan Air Force]] in 1990.{{rp|14–15}}{{cite book|last1=Cheeseman|first1=Graeme|title=Selling Mirages: The Politics of Arms Trading|publisher=Australian Foreign Policy Publications Program, Department of International Relations, Research School of Pacific Studies, Australian National University|isbn=9780731514922|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z1GvAAAAIAAJ&q=admiral+tariq+kamal+khan+high+commissioner&dq=admiral+tariq+kamal+khan+high+commissioner&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwius9Gp5evRAhXKh1QKHQiEDEsQ6wEIITAB|accessdate=31 January 2017|language=en}} In 1992, Admiral Tariq Kamal retired from the [[Foreign Service of Pakistan|Foreign Service]] and currently lives on [[Pensions in Pakistan|military pension]].{{rp|352}} ==See also== *[[Pakistan Navy]] *[[Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee (Pakistan)]] *[[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)]] *[[Chief of Air Staff (Pakistan)]] == References == {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.paknavy.gov.pk/ Official website of Pakistan Navy] {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Karamat Rahman Niazi]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Naval Staff]]|years=1983 – 1986}} {{s-aft|after=[[Iftikhar Ahmed Sirohey]]}} {{end}} {{Military of Pakistan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Khan, Tariq Kamal}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1930 births]]
