revision.text:
'''Zabdiel Boylston''', [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (March 9, 1679 in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]] – March 1, 1766) was a [[physician]] in the [[Boston]] area. He apprenticed with his father, an English surgeon named Thomas Boylston. He also studied under the Boston physician Dr. Cutler, never attending a formal medical school (the [[University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine|first medical school in North America]] was not founded until 1765).<ref name=AMB>{{Cite AMB1920|wstitle=Boylston, Zabdiel}}</ref>
Boylston is known for holding several "firsts" for an American-born physician: He performed the first surgical operation by an American physician, the first removal of gall bladder stones in 1710, and was the first to remove a breast tumor in 1718.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Toledo-Pereyra | first = Luis H. | title = Zabdiel Boylston. First American Surgeon of the English Colonies in North America | journal = Journal of Investigative Surgery | volume = 19 | issue = 1 | pages = 5–10 | publisher = Taylor & Francis | date = 2006-01-23 | issn=1521-0553 | doi = 10.1080/08941930500542413 | pmid = 16546924}}</ref>
He was a great uncle of both president [[John Adams]],<ref>{{cite web | title = John Adams autobiography, part 1, "John Adams," through 1776, sheet 2 of 53 [electronic edition] | work = Adams Family Papers: An Electronic Archive | publisher = Massachusetts Historical Society | url = http://www.masshist.org/digitaladams/ | accessdate = 2010-10-28}}</ref> and philanthropist [[Ward Nicholas Boylston]].<ref>[http://www.masshist.org/findingaids/doc.cfm?fa=fa0238 "Boylston Family Papers: 1688-1979"], [[Massachusetts Historical Society]].</ref>
==Inoculation== During a [[smallpox]] outbreak in 1721 in [[Boston]], he [[inoculation|inoculated]] about 248 people<ref>Blake, John B, ''Public Health in the Town of Boston, 1630–1822''. Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1959: p. 61, 243</ref> by applying [[pus]] from a smallpox [[Ulcer (dermatology)|sore]] to a small wound on the subjects, a method said to have been previously used in Africa. Initially, he used the method on two slaves and his own son, who was 13 at the time. This was the first introduction of inoculations to the [[United States]]. An African slave named [[Onesimus (disambiguation)|Onesimus]] taught the idea to [[Cotton Mather]], the influential New England Puritan minister.
His method was initially met by hostility and outright violence from other physicians, and many threats were made on his life, with some even threatening to hang him on the nearest tree. He was forced to hide in a private place of his house for 14 days, a secret known only by his wife. During this hostility, his family was also in a dangerous situation. His wife and children were sitting in their home and a lighted hand-grenade was thrown into the room, but the fuse fell off before an explosion could take place. Even after the violence had subsided, he visited his patients only at midnight and while disguised.<ref>Thacher, James, [https://books.google.com/books?id=_PIUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA187#v=onepage&q=boylston&f=false"American Medical Biography: Or, Memoirs of Eminent Physicians who Have Flourished in America. To which is Prefixed a Succinct History of Medical Science in the United States, from the First Settlement of the Country, Volume 1" : p. 187-188]</ref> After his initial inoculations of his son and two slaves, he was arrested for a short period of time for it (he was later released with the promise not to inoculate without government permission). In 1724, with a letter of introduction to [[James Jurin|Dr. James Jurin]] by Cotton Mather<ref>Coss, Stephen. (2016) The Fever of 1721: the epidemic that revolutionized medicine and American politics. New York: Simon & Schuster. p. 196. {{ISBN|9781476783086}}</ref> , Boylston traveled to [[London]], where he published his results as ''Historical Account of the Small-Pox Inoculated in New England'', and became a fellow of the [[Royal Society]] two years later. Afterward, he returned to Boston.
==See also== *[[Zabdiel Boylston Adams|Dr. Zabdiel Boylston Adams Jr.]] (b. Oct. 25, 1829 - d. May 1, 1902)
==References== {{reflist}}
=== Further reading === * Thacher, James, [https://books.google.com/books?id=_PIUAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover "American medical biography: or, Memoirs of eminent physicians"], Volume 1, 1828. Cf. pp. 185–192 for a biography of Zabdiel Boylston.
== External links == *{{cite web | title = Open Collections Program: Contagion, The Boston Smallpox Epidemic, 1721 | accessdate = 2008-08-27 | url = http://ocp.hul.harvard.edu/contagion/smallpox.html }} * [http://www.todayinsci.com/B/Boylston_Zabdiel/Boylston_Zabdiel.htm Today in Science History: Zabdiel Boylston]
{{Authority control}}
